questions.question: What is an Entity-Relationship (ER) diagram used for?
questions.explanation: ER diagrams visually represent entities, attributes, and relationships in a database design.

questions.question: In ER diagrams, what represents a real-world object or concept?
questions.explanation: An entity represents a distinct object or concept, such as a person, place, or thing.

questions.question: In ER diagrams, what represents a property of an entity?
questions.explanation: Attributes are properties or characteristics that describe an entity.

questions.question: What connects entities in an ER diagram?
questions.explanation: Relationships show how entities are connected or associated with each other.

questions.question: What is a one-to-many relationship?
options: One entity relates to exactly one other entity
One entity relates to many instances of another entity
Many entities relate to many entities
questions.explanation: In a one-to-many relationship, one instance of an entity relates to multiple instances of another.

questions.question: What is a many-to-many relationship?
options: One entity relates to one entity
One entity relates to many entities
Many entities relate to many entities
questions.explanation: Many-to-many relationships allow multiple instances of each entity to be related to multiple instances of the other.

questions.question: What table is needed to implement a many-to-many relationship?
questions.explanation: A junction table (or bridge table) contains foreign keys from both entities to implement many-to-many relationships.

questions.question: What describes how many instances of one entity relate to another?
questions.explanation: Cardinality specifies the numerical relationship between entity instances, like one-to-one or one-to-many.

questions.question: What is a weak entity?
options: An entity that depends on another entity for identification
questions.explanation: A weak entity cannot be uniquely identified without a relationship to another (strong) entity.

questions.question: What is the first step in database design?
questions.explanation: Requirements analysis identifies what data needs to be stored and how it will be used.
